children.value: The Seed Language is used for
Snippets only define a part of a seed. Any amount of them can be used during seed generation and locations not assigned anything by snippets will be randomly filled.
Plandomizers define the entire seed. They have to be compiled by the seed generator, but it won't add any random placements.
The randomizer ships with a set of
. This is how for instance goal modes and hints are implemented. You can use them as a baseline if you want to write similar snippets.
Seedgen will include a language server (subcommand
) that can provide features such as UberState autocomplete. A
integrating it is available. Any other editor supporting the language server protocol should be able to use it as well.

Initially custom snippets will probably work like custom headers do now: In the launcher you have to paste them into a text field, in local seedgen you can use them with the same level of support as official snippets.
A compiler will be integrated into the local seedgen. This is already implemented in the
Ori 2 stores its world data in
. It's important to understand them because they are referenced throughout the language.
Every UberState has a unique identifier consisting of two numbers.
is the UberState that tracks whether you collected the spirit light orb right of spawn.
Every UberState has a name, although it might not be unique. The name of
) has the same name, so it's impossible to address this specific UberState by its name.
To help with that we use aliases. The alias for
. By convention, aliases start with capital letters so you can tell them apart from real UberState names.
All pickup locations have aliases which you can find in
. Some selected non-pickup world states also have aliases in

props.code:
// When collecting the item right of spawn, the player will get 50 Spirit Light.
on MarshSpawn.FirstEX spirit_light(50)

children.value: // When collecting the item right of spawn, the player will get 50 Spirit Light.
There are three different types of triggers:

props.code:
// This is what the Spawn With Sword snippet does.
on spawn skill(Skill::Sword)

children.value: // This is what the Spawn With Sword snippet does.
Client Events are special triggers for specific tasks. These are all of them:
- Trigger when starting a new file,
- Trigger when starting a new file or loading the seed into an active file,
- Trigger when respawning after death, void etc.,
- Trigger on the Show Progress keybind,
- Trigger when the Inkwater trial reward text should be updated,
- Trigger when the Hollow trial reward text should be updated,
- Trigger when the Wellspring trial reward text should be updated,
- Trigger when the Woods trial reward text should be updated,
- Trigger when the Reach trial reward text should be updated,
- Trigger when the Depths trial reward text should be updated,
- Trigger when the Luma trial reward text should be updated,
- Trigger when the Wastes trial reward text should be updated,

props.code:
// Whenever the player gains or loses gorlek ore they will see a message with their current amount.
on change player.gorlekOre item_message("I love ore and now I have " + player.gorlekOre)

children.value: // Whenever the player gains or loses gorlek ore they will see a message with their current amount.
"I love ore and now I have "

props.code:
// When collecting the item right of spawn, the player will get a gorlek ore.
on MarshSpawn.FirstEX gorlek_ore()

children.value: // When collecting the item right of spawn, the player will get a gorlek ore.

props.code:
// Once the player surpasses 4000 spirit light, they will see a message.
on player.spiritLight > 4000 item_message("You're rich!")

children.value: // Once the player surpasses 4000 spirit light, they will see a message.
Conditions trigger when their value changes from

will trigger when the spirit light changes from 4000 to 4100, but it won't trigger again if it then changes from 4100 to 4150. If the player loses spirit light, dropping to 4000 or less and then goes above 4000 a second time, it will trigger again.
will trigger when the player collects the first of these two pickups, but not again when they collect the other.
will only trigger once the player collected both pickups.
Actions are instructions for the randomizer, such as giving items, showing messages or changing UberStates.
There are three different types of actions:
// This will show a message everytime the player gains or loses spirit light and has more than 4000 afterwards.
// The braces are just for easier reading.
"Spend your money already or I'll annoy you forever!"
// This function is called "item_message_with_timeout" and has two arguments:
// The message and the timeout until it disappears in seconds.
// Teleporter UberStates often have ambiguous names
There are three different types of messages:
Usually item messages are used in reaction to world changes, priority messages are used in reaction to key presses and free messages are used for advanced applications with custom message layouts.
You can use concatenation to include the return values of functions and UberStates into your messages.

props.code: on binding1 item_message(player.spiritLight + " Spirit Light owned")

children.value: Additionally, the resulting message will be processed further by the game.

props.code:
on binding1 item_message(
    "Here be colors: *blue*, #yellow#, @red@, $green$ and <purple>purple</>.\n" +
    "As a side effect, it's impossible to show any of these symbols in a message: *#@$<>"
)

children.value: "As a side effect, it's impossible to show any of these symbols in a message: *#@$<>"

props.code: on binding1 item_message("Other colors <hex_32cd32ff>are possible</> by using their hexadecimal rgba")

children.value: "Other colors <hex_32cd32ff>are possible</> by using their hexadecimal rgba"

props.code:
// This will insert the player's own keybind for the action.
on binding1 item_message("Press [OpenRandoWheel] to open the rando wheel.")

children.value: // This will insert the player's own keybind for the action.
List of possible values for keybind interpolation
Some message properties can be changed after the message has been created:

props.code: on binding1 item_message("Hi! You seem to have " + player.gorlekOre + " Gorlek Ore.")

children.value: Item messages will enter a queue in the top center region of the screen. If too many messages are already visible, new ones will wait until they have space to appear. By default item messages disappear after a 4 second timeout; the timeout only runs while they're visible.

props.code: on binding1 item_message_with_timeout("Hi! You seem to have " + player.gorlekOre + " Gorlek Ore.", 2)
on binding1 priority_message("Pressing this bind fills you with determination", 6)

children.value: "Pressing this bind fills you with determination"

Priority messages will appear instantly at the top center of the screen. Only 1 priority message can be visible at once, previous ones will be destroyed. Item messages will move out of the way as necessary to show the priority message.

props.code: controlled_priority_message(id: String, message: String, timeout: Float)

children.value: with an id to change its properties later. Note that the position of a priority message cannot be changed.

Free messages will not interact with other messages in any way. They can appear on top of other messages and on top of eachother. It's your responsibility to control their position. They won't disappear by themselves, you have to set their timeout or destroy them manually.

props.code:
on binding1 free_message(
    "confirmation",
    "Just making sure, you did read this message in its entirety?\n" +
    "[Binding2] Yes"
)
on binding2 destroy_message("confirmation")

children.value: "Just making sure, you did read this message in its entirety?\n"
Starts a timeout for the message to disappear.
Controls whether the background box behind the text is rendered.

props.code: set_message_position(id: String, x: Float, y: Float)

children.value: How the position is interpreted depends on the message's
, which approximates the default position of other messages at the top center of the screen.
Controls the text alignment, which will only matter on multiline messages.
exists but we're not sure if it works.
For most cases you may prefer to use
Controls which part of the message box its
For most cases you may prefer to use
Controls which part of the message box its
For most cases you may prefer to use
"I will appear in the top left corner."
"I will appear in the top left corner."
In essence, the first part of the screen position controls the
. This only allows for a subset of possible alignment and anchor combinations, but it's useful for the most common cases.
By default, message boxes fit their content. Using this you can instead set a fixed width.
uses the game's internal positioning, which doesn't account for different resolutions and is not recommended.
normalizes coordinates so that (0, 0) is the top left corner and (1, 1) the bottom right corner of the screen.
places the message at in-world coordinates, meaning it's not relative to the camera anymore at all.
Every instance of this function in your code will be assigned a random spirit light name. This way random spirit light names within the same seed always appear at the same places.

explicitely since it's inferred when you use an UberState identifier. The type of the return value depends on the type of the UberState.

on binding1 store(player.health, -1) // Setting health to a negative value kills the player

The expected type of the value depends on the type of the UberState.

You can store temporary values in variables. This can be useful for calculations, or to pass values to custom functions. Variables will not be stored in the savefile, so generally you should not assume they keep existing beyond the current frame. If you need persistent values, use

children.value: for a list of possible values.
, you cannot enable syncing for UberStates which aren't synced by default.
// This defines a custom function called "exciting_gorlek_ore" which displays a message and gives a gorlek ore.
"It's finally here! Fresh out of the mines!"
// Now you can reuse the function to avoid repetition.
Passing arguments to custom functions is not currently supported. Use

Where triggers and actions are instructions for the randomizer, commands are instructions for the compiler and seed generator. They provide features such as code splitting, adding settings to your snippet or customizing random placements.
You can include existing snippets, or split your plandomizer across multiple files if you want.

props.code:
!include("wisps")  // wisps is the snippet adding the wisps goal mode
!include("bonus_item_core", extra_double_jump)

on binding1 extra_double_jump()

children.value: // wisps is the snippet adding the wisps goal mode
If you want to include custom snippets they need to be in the snippet or plandomizer folder.
When making a plandomizer, you probably want to include some of the official snippets. You don't need to copy them anywhere, simply add them as includes. Most notably,

is included in every generated seed and is responsible for many randomizer critical tasks such as enabling teleport anywhere. Here is a selection of includes to get your plandomizer into a similar starting point as a generated seed with the gorlek preset:
// This allows other snippets to !include cool_custom_item
// Other snippets can reference this using on_event and add actions to the keybind_event function.
// You can call the function and whatever other snippets have added will happen.
// This will show a message and give a gorlek ore if the snippets below are used
// Now you can use the icon anywhere
The icon path starts in the snippet or plandomizer folder.
After compilation the icon will be bundled into the seed, with this you can use custom icons in your plandomizer without requiring the players to download the icons separately.
// This icon ships with the randomizer
// Now you can use the icon anywhere
The randomizer ships with a set of
. They will be installed into a folder called assets, which is why you need to prefix
in front of all the paths.
are allowed here. It's not possible to persistently store strings.
"This message shows with a delay of 7.5 seconds."
Item pool changes are only relevant for snippets used in seed generation, they do nothing for plandos.

props.code:
// Add a second Burrow to the item pool
!add(skill(Skill::Burrow), 1)

children.value: // Add a second Burrow to the item pool

// This is what the No Launch snippet does
!remove(skill(Skill::Launch), 1)

children.value: // This is what the No Launch snippet does

props.code:
fun custom_item() {}
!item_data(
    custom_item(),
    "Custom Item",  // Name when being placed in a shop
    1000,  // Base price when being placed in a shop
    "I assure you it's great",  // Description when being placed in a shop
    Equipment::Invisibility,  // Icon when being placed in a shop
    MapIcon::BonusItem  // Map icon for the spoiler filter
)

children.value: // Name when being placed in a shop
// Base price when being placed in a shop
// Description when being placed in a shop
// Icon when being placed in a shop
// Map icon for the spoiler filter
"How much money is inside the treasure chest"
Snippet settings will be available for configuration in the launcher or seedgen cli when generating random seeds with the snippet, but they can also be controlled by a plandomizer using
// Include knowledge hints (for example, in your plando), but turn off the regen hint (since it doesn't fit your plando's style/progression)
This command is useful in plandomizers, when you want to include snippets out of your control and change their configuration.
You probably shouldn't use it in snippets intended for seed generation, where configuration is supposed to be controller by the player generating the seed.
Note that you have to put the value inside a string. This is because making good compilers is hard.

props.code:
// This is a black box in the void. Useful if you want to have some kind of menu before starting the plandomizer.
!spawn(-3537, -5881)

children.value: // This is a black box in the void. Useful if you want to have some kind of menu before starting the plandomizer.
Setting the spawn location is only relevant for plandos, it does nothing for snippets used in seed generation.
You can use compile-time evaluation to conditionally include parts of your code depending on

or to improve code readability without hurting performance. Compile-time evaluation happens during seed generation or plandomizer compilation, it will be completely optimized away in the finished seed.
// In case you can't read hexcolors in your brain, giving them names might help
// In the resulting seed, this gives exactly the same output as:
// In the resulting seed, only one of the two sections below will be included
"How many clones of Motay should assist you"
"Hey! I'm Motay! I will help you!"
These values will be different every time the snippet is used or the plandomizer is compiled. In the finished seed, the value won't change anymore.
Values that can change randomly while playing the seed still need to be implemented.
will remove one random value from the pool created with
. If you draw from the same pool again, that value will be gone. If you attempt to draw from a pool which is already empty, compilation will fail.
These are very specialized commands to support our hint systems.

This is useful when having to write custom logic for a snippet such as no combat.

props.code:
// Sword will be placed somewhere in Marsh
!preplace(skill(Skill::Sword), Zone::Marsh)

children.value: // Sword will be placed somewhere in Marsh
Preplacements happen before any logic, they are placed in a random location of the specified zone which is not already occupied by other preplacements.
Snippets may add annotations to influence how they are presented to the user. They do nothing in plandomizers.
The snippet will be invisible to the user. It only exists to be
